prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 1603+001 - band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 100 GHz continuum emission from a resolved, synchrotron-emitting jet. The jet is approximately 10" in length, extending from a compact (point source) bright 'core'. The goal is to resolve the knotty structure in the jet, which is expected to have peak fluxes on the order of 1 mJy in individual features. Thus, our target flux for exposure time calculations is 50 microJy in order to ensure good signal/noise on the faintest parts of the jet.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard wide-band continuum observing for maximum sensitivity (observations are targeting very broad-band synchrotron emission).

The jet has a total length of about 10", but is only about 0.5" wide. The individual features are typically on the order of 0.5-1" with similar separations, and previous VLA imaging, with which we wish to compare, has a beamsize on the order of 0.5" and this is our requested angular resolution. The widest part of the jet approaches 2" only at the very end, so we adopt a largest angular scale of 4" to be safe.

The brightest part of the jet is the core, at 20 mJy. However our goal is to detect the knots and structure in the extended jet, where the faintest features are on the order of 1-5 mJy. The target RMS of 50 uJy gives us a S/N of 20-100, sufficient to robustly detect even the faintest structures in the jet.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 1603+001 - band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 250 GHz continuum emission from a resolved, synchrotron-emitting jet. The jet is approximately 10" in length, extending from a compact (point source) bright 'core'. The goal is to resolve the knotty structure in the jet, which is expected to have peak fluxes on the order of 1 mJy in individual features. Thus, our target flux for exposure time calculations is 50 microJy in order to ensure good signal/noise on the faintest parts of the jet.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard wide-band continuum observing for maximum sensitivity (observations are targeting very broad-band synchrotron emission).

The jet has a total length of about 10", but is only about 0.5" wide. The brightest part of the jet is the core, at 20 mJy. However our goal is to detect the knots and structure in the extended jet, where the faintest features are on the order of 1-5 mJy. The target RMS of 50 uJy gives us a S/N of 20-100, sufficient to robustly detect even the faintest structures in the jet.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 2209+080 - band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 100 GHz continuum emission from a resolved, synchrotron-emitting jet. The jet is approximately 7" in length, extending from a compact (point source) bright 'core'. The goal is to resolve the knotty structure in the jet, which is expected to have peak fluxes on the order of 1 mJy in individual features. Thus, our target flux for exposure time calculations is 50 microJy in order to ensure good signal/noise on the faintest parts of the jet.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard wide-band continuum observing for maximum sensitivity (observations are targeting very broad-band synchrotron emission).

The jet has a total length of about 7", but is about 1.5" wide. The individual features are typically on the order of 0.5 - 1" with similar separations, and previous VLA imaging, with which we wish to compare, has a beamsize on the order of 0.5" and this is our requested angular resolution. The widest part of the jet approaches 3.5" only at the very end, so we adopt a largest angular scale of 4".

While the brightest part of the jet, usually the unresolved 'core' near the black hole, can reach flux densities as high as 0.65 Jy, our goal is to detect the knots and structure in the extended jet, where the faintest features are on the order of 1-5 mJy. The target RMS of 50 uJy gives us a S/N of 20-100, sufficient to robustly detect even the faintest structures in the jet.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 2209+080 - band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 250 GHz continuum emission from a resolved, synchrotron-emitting jet. The jet is approximately 7" in length, extending from a compact (point source) bright 'core'. The goal is to resolve the knotty structure in the jet, which is expected to have peak fluxes on the order of 1 mJy in individual features. Thus, our target flux for exposure time calculations is 50 microJy in order to ensure good signal/noise on the faintest parts of the jet. The largest angular scale expected to be resolved is a few arcseconds (5" in the form).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard wide-band continuum observing for maximum sensitivity (observations are targeting very broad-band synchrotron emission).

While the brightest part of the jet, usually the unresolved 'core' near the black hole, can reach flux densities as high as 0.65 Jy, our goal is to detect the knots and structure in the extended jet, where the faintest features are on the order of 1-5 mJy. The target RMS of 50 uJy gives us a S/N of 20-100, sufficient to robustly detect even the faintest structures in the jet.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard wide-band continuum observing for maximum sensitivity (observations are targeting very broad-band synchrotron emission).

The jet has a total length of about 6", but is only about 2" wide. While the brightest part of the jet, usually the unresolved 'core' near the black hole, can reach flux densities as high as 1 Jy, our goal is to detect the knots and structure in the extended jet, where the faintest features are on the order of 5-10 mJy. The target RMS of 50 uJy gives us a S/N of at least 100, sufficient to robustly detect even the faintest structures in the jet.

The individual features are typically on the order of 0.5 - 1" with similar separations, and previous VLA imaging, with which we wish to compare, has a beamsize on the order of 0.5" and this is our requested angular resolution. The widest part of the jet is 1" so we adopt a largest angular scale of 4".

While the brightest part of the jet, usually the unresolved 'core' near the black hole, can reach flux densities as high as 3 Jy, our goal is to detect the knots and structure in the extended jet, where the faintest features are on the order of 0.5-1 mJy. The target RMS of 50 uJy gives us a S/N of 10-20, sufficient to robustly detect even the faintest structures in the jet.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 1421-0643 - band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 100 GHz continuum emission from a resolved, synchrotron-emitting jet. The jet is approximately 5" in length, extending from a compact (point source) bright 'core'. The goal is to resolve the knotty structure in the jet, which is expected to have peak fluxes on the order of 1 mJy in individual features. Thus, our target flux for exposure time calculations is 50 microJy in order to ensure good signal/noise on the faintest parts of the jet. The largest angular scale expected to be resolved is a few arcseconds (5" in the form).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard wide-band continuum observing for maximum sensitivity (observations are targeting very broad-band synchrotron emission).

The jet has a total length of about 5", but is only about 1" wide. The individual features are typically on the order of 0.5 - 1" with similar separations, and previous VLA imaging, with which we wish to compare, has a beamsize on the order of 0.5" and this is our requested angular resolution. The widest part of the jet is 3" so we adopt a largest angular scale of 4".

While the brightest part of the jet, usually the unresolved 'core' near the black hole, can reach flux densities as high as 100 mJy, our goal is to detect the knots and structure in the extended jet, where the faintest features are on the order of 0.5-1 mJy. The target RMS of 50 uJy gives us a S/N of 10-20, sufficient to robustly detect even the faintest structures in the jet.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard wide-band continuum observing for maximum sensitivity (observations are targeting very broad-band synchrotron emission).

The jet has a total length of about 5", but is only about 1" wide. The individual features are typically on the order of 0.5 - 1" with similar separations, and previous VLA imaging, with which we wish to compare, has a beamsize on the order of 0.5" and this is our requested angular resolution. The widest part of the jet is 3" so we adopt a largest angular scale of 4".

While the brightest part of the jet, usually the unresolved 'core' near the black hole, can reach flux densities as high as 100 mJy, our goal is to detect the knots and structure in the extended jet, where the faintest features are on the order of 0.5-1 mJy. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose high-resolution mm imaging of 13 AGN with powerful kpc-scale jets, in order to accurately map the synchrotron emission of the jet as it extends out from the host galaxy. Chandra X-ray observations have revealed very hard X-ray spectra which has lead to the prevailing interpretation that the X-rays are due to inverse-Compton upscattering of CMB photons (IC/CMB) by a jet which is still relativistic on kpc scales. However, very recent work by our group has shown that the gamma-ray flux implied by this mechanism is not detected, implying a mysterious second synchrotron component. In order to positively rule out the IC/CMB model in a larger sample, we must acquire an accurate measurement of the synchrotron spectrum of the jet near the sub-mm peak in order to exactly predict the gamma-ray spectrum expected & interpret the existing upper limits. With the ALMA imaging we propose, we will be able to settle over a decade of ambiguity about the emission mechanism of the X-rays, and place strong limits on the their speeds on kpc scales.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, Maryland, Baltimore County, University of
Physics & Space Sciences Dept, Florida Institute of Technology
